review.title: Place classification with a graph regularized deep neural network model
review.abstract: Place classification is a fundamental ability that a robot should possess to carry out effective human-robot interactions. It is a nontrivial classification problem which has attracted many research. In recent years, there is a high exploitation of Artificial Intelligent algorithms in robotics applications. Inspired by the recent successes of deep learning methods, we propose an end-to-end learning approach for the place classification problem. With the deep architectures, this methodology automatically discovers features and contributes in general to higher classification accuracies. The pipeline of our approach is composed of three parts. Firstly, we construct multiple layers of laser range data to represent the environment information in different levels of granularity. Secondly, each layer of data is fed into a deep neural network model for classification, where a graph regularization is imposed to the deep architecture for keeping local consistency between adjacent samples. Finally, the predicted labels obtained from all the layers are fused based on confidence trees to maximize the overall confidence. Experimental results validate the effective- ness of our end-to-end place classification framework in which both the multi-layer structure and the graph regularization promote the classification performance. Furthermore, results show that the features automatically learned from the raw input range data can achieve competitive results to the features constructed based on statistical and geometrical information.

sections.text: To confirm the effectiveness of our multi-layered learning system, we are conducting experiments with six indoor data sets collected from six international universities (including the Centre for Autonomous Systems at the University of Technology Sydney, several buildings at the University of Freiburg, the German Research Centre for Artificial Intelligence in Saarbrücken, and the Intel Laboratory in Seattle). As we have already explained, the range data collected at the GVG nodes with the 2D rangefinder, which has a maximum range of 30 meters and a horizontal field of view of 180 meters, can be noted that the classes defined by humans are somewhat vague and rich according to the different functions of the locations. However, the 2D range data does not contain enough discriminatory information to classify all of these human-designed classes. Therefore, we consider three target classes as: Class 1 room designed for a small number of individuals, office, kitchen, stairwell as elevator.

We implemented a multi-layered learning framework, including building multi-layered input and decision-making on the multi-layered results. Each layer of input was fed into a semi-supervised feature model.

sections.text: Experimental results showed that the higher layer input data led to higher classification accuracy, confirming the effectiveness of the multi-layer structure. By conducting semi-supervised learning with or without graph regulation, we also demonstrated that graph regulation helps to enhance classification performance by maintaining local consistency. In addition, the trust-based merger results achieved results comparable to the state-of-the-art method. In short, we achieved generalization capability and preserved local consistency in our end-to-end classification framework. Future work is to apply our framework to other types of sensor data, such as RGB-D data, which have more representative and discriminatory capabilities.
